title-group.article-title: How to Decrease the Amortization Bias
title-group.subtitle: Experience vs. Rules

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2017 by the Journal of Financial Education

abstract.p: We conduct an experimental study that tests the effectiveness of de-biasing a certain form of exponential growth bias found in household finance debt decisions, called the amortization bias. We provide participants with a short tutorial based on one of three learning methods: experiential learning, learning a simple rule-of-thumb, and an extended, but more accurate rule-of-thumb. Immediately after completing these tutorials, we retest for the amortization bias and find a significant bias improvement in all three treatments. More importantly, we test the same participants with similar debt scenarios approximately three weeks later, and find that those who had previously received a debt tutorial maintain a significantly larger bias improvement over the control group. However, during this short period, most of the individuals who learned the rules-of-thumb couldnâ€™t remember the rule and reverted back to their biased answers, while the experiential learning group were able to better retain their bias improvement.
